III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In 2021, unidentified staff allowed unidentified youth to fight, and a
youth was hospitalized as a result.
Investigation DCWL received these allegations on 9/29/23 via DCWL online
complaint. The incidents were alleged to have occurred sometime
in 2021.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
The identity of the Complainant is unknown. Based on the written
allegations, he may be a former resident who spent time at
Wolverine Center in 2021. I attempted to reach Complainant on
9/30/23 via email and phone. The email I sent was returned
marked “undeliverable”, and the phone number provided was out
of service. Complainant omitted his last name, so I was unable to
search MISACWIS to determine if he ever resided at the facility.
Given that the alleged incident(s) occurred two years ago, without
approximate dates, descriptions, or names of the youths or staff
involved, it was not possible to complete a focused investigation.
However, a search of DCWL reports from 2020 – 2022 showed
similar allegations were already investigated in that timeframe.
I reviewed all investigation reports completed from 2020 – 2022
and identified those with similar allegations related to staff not
intervening in fights. These reports are listed below:
SIR 2020C0108053 by myself dated 9/3/20. Rule 112 (4) (a) and
(b) were cited for two staff members failing to intervene in a youth
fight. As a result of this investigation, adverse action was taken,
and the facility was placed on a First Provisional license and was
restored to a Regular license in 2021.
2

SIR 2020C0108073 by myself dated 10/9/20. For an allegation
that staff failed to protect two youth being beaten by other youths,
no violations were established.
SIR 2021C0103029 by Consultant 2 dated 7/28/21. For an
allegation that staff failed to intervene in a fight, no violations were
established.
SIR 2022C0219023 by Consultant 3 dated 3/3/22. For an
allegation that staff failed to intervene in a fight, no violations were
established.
SIR 2022C0219030 by Consultant 3 dated 3/18/22. For an
allegation that staff were unaware of an altercation between
youths and did not intervene, no violations were established.
SIR 2022C0219044 by Consultant 3 dated 6/14/22. For an
allegation that staff were unaware of a youth being assaulted by
another youth, no violations were established.
SIR 2022C0201513 by Consultant 2 dated 8/3/22. For an
allegation that a youth was hit by another youth and it was
unknown if staff intervened, no violations were established.
For the present allegations, I arrived at the facility unannounced
on 10/03/23 accompanied by Government Worker 1. We jointly
interviewed Program Director. She said there are no residents at
the facility who have been there since 2021. The resident who
has been there the longest was admitted on 5/24/23.
I interviewed Youth K and Supervisors 1 and 2 separately and
jointly with Government Worker 1. All youth and staff interviewed
denied knowledge of any staff allowing or encouraging youths to
fight or failing to intervene in fights between youths.
Government Worker 1 interviewed Staff 1, and Youths L, M and C.
The youths all reported that staff intervene in fights by getting in
between youths who are fighting. Staff 1 reported that staff
intervene in fights by using verbal intervention and physically
blocking and separating youths who are fighting.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
3

Analysis From 2020 through 2022, seven investigations were completed by
DCWL for complaints alleging staff failed to intervene in youth
fights. In 2020, licensing rule violations were established in one of
the seven incidents. The other six incidents were investigated,
and no rule violations were found.
Given that the alleged incident(s) happened two years ago,
without descriptions, or names of the youths or staff involved, it
cannot be determined if any incidents that were not already
investigated occurred.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a
youth’s background or appearance or mental state. Yelling,
threats, ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In 2021, unidentified staff verbally abused and name-called
unidentified youth.
Investigation Given that the alleged incident(s) happened two years ago,
without descriptions, or names of the youths or staff involved, it is
not possible to complete a focused investigation at this time.
I searched and located completed special investigation reports
from 2020 – 2022 with similar allegations regarding Wolverine
Center. I found one existing report with a similar allegation that
staff called youth names. SIR 2022C0219023 by Consultant 3
dated 3/03/22 was completed with no violations found.
Supervisor 1 and 2, Staff 1, and Youths M and L all reported that
they have never heard a staff member call youths names or
antagonize them.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
4

Analysis Given that the alleged incident(s) occurred two years ago, without
descriptions, or names of the youths or staff involved, it cannot be
determined if incidents that were not already investigated
occurred.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
